newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean banks said planning to cut interest rates.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean banks said planning to cut interest rates.

text.p: South Korean banks plan to cut lending rates in line with the central bank's plan to lower the bank reserve requirement ratio from November 8, domestic media reported on Thursday.
Yonhap said the nation's four leading commercial banks, including Cho Hung Bank, planned to cut their prime lending rates by 0.25 percentage point to 8.5 percent when the reserve ratio was lowered.
The other three are Hanil Bank, the Commercial Bank of Korea and the Korea First Bank.
Yonhap said other commercial banks were also considering lowering their lending rates.
Korea Times said state-run banks would also cut both lending and deposit rates by 0.25-0.5 percentage points from next month.
The central Bank of Korea on Thursday released details of cuts in reserve requirements to an average of 5.5 percent from 7.8 percent.
The move is aimed at making local banks more competitive and creating conditions for lower interest rates, the bank said in a statement.
